Issues.Title: Update templates to set DPI Awareness to System Aware by default
Issues.Body:
.NET Core apps are more likely than not to run on more modern hardware with a higher pixel density. Given that, we should default all new apps to be System Aware. We'll update this in the templates using  `Application.SetHighDpiMode(HighDpiMode.SystemAware);` in program.cs file and the equivalent in VB.

@OliaG to make porting of apps smoother and work well in the new designer we should also update porting guides to include calling that method in Main().
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Update templates to set DPI Awareness to System Aware by default" (#1593)

Issues.Title: WIP: Fixing DataGridViewCell AccessibleObject Value.IsReadOnly property
Issues.Body:
<!-- Please read CONTRIBUTING.md before submitting a pull request -->

Fixes #1578 


## Proposed changes

- Override the IsReadOnly property for DataGridViewCell AccessibleObject

<!-- We are in TELL-MODE the following section must be completed -->

## Customer Impact

- The Narrator will say "readonly" for readonly cells

## Regression? 

- No

## Risk

- None, this is a minimal extension.

<!-- end TELL-MODE -->


## Screenshots <!-- Remove this section if PR does not change UI -->

### Before
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/49272759/62694277-b01ac980-b9dc-11e9-9e83-681da817ba64.png)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/49272759/62704190-75705b80-b9f3-11e9-838d-5f314a98bdb4.png)

<!-- TODO -->

### After
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/49272759/62694079-52867d00-b9dc-11e9-8f4a-b1a1cebc5acd.png)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/49272759/62703993-14488800-b9f3-11e9-9847-e52d613176d3.png)

<!-- TODO -->


## Test methodology <!-- How did you ensure quality? -->

- Unit test (DataGridViewCellAccessibleObjectTests.cs) 

## Accessibility testing  <!-- Remove this section if PR does not change UI -->
- Manual testing with using the Inspect tool
- Manual testing with using the Narrator
<!--
     Microsoft prioritizes making our products accessible. 
     WinForms has a key role in allowing developers to create accessible apps. 
     
     When submitting a change which impacts UI in any way, including adding new UI or
     modifying existing controls the developer needs to run the Accessibility Insights
     tool (https://accessibilityinsights.io/) and verify that there are no changes or
     regressions. 
     
     The developer should run the Fast Pass over the impacted control(s) and provide
     a snapshot of the passing results along with before/after snapshots of the UI.
     More info: (https://accessibilityinsights.io/docs/en/web/getstarted/fastpass)
  -->


 

## Test environment(s) <!-- Remove any that don't apply -->
- .NET Core SDK: 3.0.0-preview9-19407-06
- Microsoft Windows [Version 10.0.18362.239]

<!-- use `dotnet --info` -->


<!-- Mention language, UI scaling, or anything else that might be relevant -->

Issues.Title: Fix xmldoc
Issues.Body:
<!-- Please read CONTRIBUTING.md before submitting a pull request -->

Fixes #


## Proposed changes

- Purely cosmetic change that increases xml-doc spacing to 2 after `///`.  
The increased spacing makes it slightly easier to read the comments in the code.
The change is done in VS using regex `///\s([^< ])` -> `///  $1`
- Fix and add xml-doc
<!-- We are in TELL-MODE the following section must be completed -->

## Customer Impact

- None

## Regression? 

- No

## Risk

- None

<!-- end TELL-MODE -->

Issues.Title: [Accessibility Insights] An element of the given ControlType must support the Text pattern for edit controls: TextBox/MaskedTextBox/ComboBox/NumericUpDown/DomainUpDown
Issues.Body:
* .NET Core Version: .NET Core 3.0.100-preview8-013656 from release branch
* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework? Yes

**Affected controls:**
TextBox/MaskedTextBox/ComboBox/NumericUpDown/DomainUpDown

**Problem description:**
1.	Install the .NET Core 3.0 SDK from https://github.com/dotnet/core-sdk.
2.	Open the attached ‘NumericUpDown_DomainUpDown’ .NET Core app in VS.
[NumericUpDown_DomainUpDown.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/3480418/NumericUpDown_DomainUpDown.zip)
3.	Build and run it.
4.	Start Accessibility Insights for Windows and test NumericUpDown and DomainUpDown controls in Form.

**Actual behavior:** <!-- callstack for crashes / exceptions -->
An element of the given ControlType doesn’t support the Text pattern. 
Violation: [Section 508 502.3.10](https://www.access-board.gov/guidelines-and-standards/communications-and-it/about-the-ict-refresh/final-rule/single-file-version#502-interoperability-assistive-technology) 
Please see the below Screenshot:
NumericUpDown:
![NumericUpDown](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/45864017/62684112-8d93ab00-b9f2-11e9-819b-a3519503fcd7.png)

DomainUpDown:
![DomainUpDown](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/45864017/62684118-91273200-b9f2-11e9-94f5-3ed3f13f8644.png)

**Expected behavior:**
NumericUpDown and DomainUpDown eidt should support the Text pattern.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[Accessibility Insights] An element of the given ControlType must support the Text pattern for edit controls: TextBox/MaskedTextBox/ComboBox/NumericUpDown/DomainUpDown" (#1588)

Issues.Title: Accessibility: [Inspect] The name of spinner under “PageUpDown” spinner in PrintPreview dialog should be consistent with .Net framework behavior
Issues.Body:
* .NET Core Version: .Net 3.0 SDK Preview8 013656 build
* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: No

**Repro Steps:**
1.	Open attached “PrintDemo” .Net Core app in VS
[PrintDemo.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/3476187/PrintDemo.zip)

2.	Build and run it, click the “Preview” button to show the Print Preview dialog
3.	Open Inspect and focus on the last one: ToolStripNumericUpDown in PrintPreviewToolStrip

**Actual behavior:** 
The name of spinner under “PageUpDown” spinner  is “ToolStripNumericUpDownControl” spinner, is not same as .net framework behavior. Please see following screenshot:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/26474449/62609968-8caa2e80-b8b7-11e9-887b-1de17c6b6841.png)


**Expected behavior:**
The name of spinner under “PageUpDown” spinner in Core should keep up with .Net framework, should be “NumericUpDown” spinner.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Accessibility: [Inspect] The name of spinner under “PageUpDown” spinner in PrintPreview dialog should be consistent with .Net framework behavior" (#1579)

Issues.Title: The DataGridViewComboBoxColumn cannot be displayed as combobox mode when the DisplayStyle property is set to Nothing.
Issues.Body:
* .NET Core Version: (.Net Core SDK 5.0.100.13662 build from master branch)
* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: Yes

**Steps to reproduce:**

1. Create a Winforms .Net Core application.
2. Add DataGridView control, then add a DataGridViewComboBoxColumn column.
3. Set the DisplayStyle property of DataGridViewComboBoxColumn as Nothing.
4. Build and run it.
[WindowsFormsApp6.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/3479985/WindowsFormsApp6.zip)

**Actual:** 
The DataGridViewComboBoxColumn cannot be displayed as combobox mode when the DisplayStyle property is set to Nothing.

**Expected:** 
From Merrie comment：Add the Obsolete attribute for the type so that we can warn developers not to use it due to accessibility issues.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "The DataGridViewComboBoxColumn cannot be displayed as combobox mode when the DisplayStyle property is set to Nothing." (#1587)

Issues.Title: Remove pointstruct and friends
Issues.Body:
## Proposed changes

- Remove `POINTSTRUCT` preferring `Point` which marshals the same
- Remove `_POINTL` preferring `Point` which marshals the same
- Remove `tagPOINTF`, preferring `PointF` which marshals the same
- Remove `tagSIZEL`, preferring `Size` which marshals the same
- Remove `tagSIZE`, preferring `Size` which marshals the same
- Remove `SIZE`, preferring `Size` which marshals the same

## Customer Impact

- Reduced allocations as we now use classes instead of structs

## Regression? 

- No

## Risk

- Minimal

## Test methodology <!-- How did you ensure quality? -->

- Existing tests and #1530 

Extracted from #1508

Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "Remove pointstruct and friends" (#1583)

Issues.Title: [Accessibility]: Incorrect control type of dropdown menu items
Issues.Body:
* .NET Core Version: 3.0.100-preview8-013392
* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: Yes

**Original bug:**
- [Bug 937670: ](https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/937670)[Screen Reader - SSMA - Create new project] Incorrect control type is defined for all menus like 'File and Edit and View and Tools...' on SSMA.
<!-- Read https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/master/Documentation/issue-guide.md -->

**Problem description:**
- ToolStrip menu items have incorrect Accessibility ControlType property value when they are expanded. ToolStrip behavior should be like as in the Notepad.

**Actual behavior:** <!-- callstack for crashes / exceptions -->
- ToolStripDropDown item doesn't change his ControlType property value when it is expanded
- The navigation tree has an extra "toolbar".
- The Inspect can't get access to item's AccessibleObject when the mouse is over it

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/49272759/62624995-04667080-b92d-11e9-8797-390fd59c030e.png)

**Expected behavior:**
- ToolStripDropDown item has "menu item" control type when it is collapsed.
- ToolStripDropDown item has "menu" control type when it is expanded and has separate space in the navigation tree.
- The navigation tree doesn't have an extra "toolbar".
- The Inspect can get access to item's AccessibleObject when the mouse is over it

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/49272759/62625513-05e46880-b92e-11e9-8c82-050bebe9f81e.png)


**Minimal repro:**
- Create Core test app
- Add MenuStrip control
- Add menu items to MenuStrip control
- Add nested items to some dropdown MenuStrip item
- Open the Inspect and check the accessibility navigation tree
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[Accessibility]: Incorrect control type of dropdown menu items" (#1582)

Issues.Title: Consider enabling some xunit analyzers
Issues.Body:
We have done this in corefx and it's helped find some incorrect use of asserts and xunit attributes. Might be something the community is interested in doing - enabling one rule at a time as we have been doing.

original change https://github.com/dotnet/corefx/pull/38676
subsequent enablings https://github.com/dotnet/corefx/commits/master/src/CodeAnalysis.ruleset
more pending https://github.com/dotnet/corefx/pull/40079
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Consider enabling some xunit analyzers" (#1577)

Issues.Title: Remove unused .RESX files from Templates
Issues.Body:
<!-- Please read CONTRIBUTING.md before submitting a pull request -->

Fixes #1479

## Proposed changes
- remove `.resx` files form both language templates
- remove some unnecessary usings for the c# template 

<!-- We are in TELL-MODE the following section must be completed -->

## Customer Impact
- no longer see extraneous usings in startup `Program.cs`
- no longer see unused `.resx` files in startup project

## Regression? 

- No

## Risk
- These are compiling just as they were before my change, so I see little risk. There is, of course, some risk that the templates would not work at all. We should have CTI validate the templates.

<!-- end TELL-MODE -->

Issues.Title: Adding new field to CloseReason Enum
Issues.Body:
Link to article:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.windows.forms.closereason?redirectedfrom=MSDN&view=netframework-4.8

Problem:
When you describe the fields of this Enumeration you state that the 'UserClosing' happens when: "The user is closing the form through the user interface (UI)". But this also happens when you use 'Close' method for a form in your code.
It would be great to distinguish the UI Closing from the code closing. 

Link to previous conversation about this issue: https://github.com/dotnet/dotnet-api-docs/issues/2844
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Adding new field to CloseReason Enum" (#1570)

Issues.Title: WIP: Fix MSO interfaces
Issues.Body:
This fixes MSO component interfaces so that they correctly match the COM interface definitions. It also hardens against being invoked with null pointers.

See related issue: #247

Need to define the interop scenarios with Office to fully test this. Wanted to make sure this PR is active for visibility. (And to prevent others from replicating the work I did here.)


## Proposed changes

- Update component manager interfaces to be correct on both x32 and x64
- Remove unnecessary app domain related proxies
- Simplify component manager construction logic

## Customer Impact

- Message processing is faster (removed layers, lighter com interop when hosted)
- APIs are now correct and safer (particularly on x64)

## Regression? 

- No

## Risk

- Moderate for hosted scenarios (with a present IMsoComponentManager or hosting a native control that needs it), but outside of that low. I don't believe that is a common scenario for this release.

## Test methodology

- Ran existing tests (this impacts the message loop, so it is broadly hit)
- Added basic tests (there were none)

 The tests that still don't exist are message pumping related. Can probably do it if we fire up a separate thread for that specific test with it's own message pump?
